And since in this question of the Sabbath there is now adayes a kind of appealing from the fourth Commandment to the light of nature, whose eye-sight hath been long ago decayed, me thinks, we may well allow her the use of Art and experience as spectacles, or perspective glasses, through which she may see both further and clearer, then otherwise
of her self she can do, and rather blesse God that affords us any help that way, then lightly esteeme the lessons we may learn thereby.

div.head: The fifth Exception.
div.p: If God discovers his will concerning the offering up unto him external and bloody sacrifices of sheep, oxen, &c. upon this discovery man by the light of nature in such manner qualified as you speak of in the beginning of this inserted addition) may discern and acknowledge it to be agreeable to naturall and religious equitie, to offer up such sacrifices unto him; and yet the thing it selfe, viz. this kind of offering or sacrificing is not for all that naturalis & perpetui juris. So here might some one say in this case.

div.head: The Answer.
div.p:
If God had discovered his will
concerning the offering up unto him externall and bloody sacrifices of sheep, oxen, &c. at the same time, and in the same manner as he did discover his will concerning the setting apart one day of seven for a weekly Sabbath; I should have thought that discoverie a strong inducement to conceive that to be naturalis & perpetui juris, as well as this. For though as the Bishop of Ely speaks, pa. 54. these circumstantiall accidents make no alteration of the internall and naturall forme or qualitie of the materiall object of this (or indeed of any other) Commandment, nor conclude by a necessary inference all those, and onely those precepts that then, and so were uttered to be simply and perpetually morall, yet they afford a verie probable Argument to perswade us, that all that which was then and so delivered, was purposely
intended by God to be of the same binding power to the same persons. But to let that passe. When God did discover to his people his will concerning the offering up unto him externall and bloodie sacrifices of sheep, oxen, &c. Deut. 12.4. &c. he did withall discover to his people that his will was not to require or to permit them the performance of that service every where, but expresly confined them unto the place which he should chuse to put his Name there. And the Apostle St. Paul tells us plainly, Hebr. 9.9, 10. that Gods intent and purpose was not that his people should stand alwayes alike obliged unto those observances, but onely untill the time of Reformation. There is no such limitation for the sanctification of the Sabbath day, nor did the Jews ever understand it so.

And yet I rest not in this answer
neither, because I know that though the offering up of bloudy sacrifices were limited and confined in respect of place, yet other ceremoniall observances were not. Therefore I goe further and say, that God discovering his will in this kinde, upon this discovery man by the light of nature in such manner qualified, as I speake of, might discerne and acknowledge it indeed to be agreeable unto naturall and religious equitie, to offer up such sacrifices unto him. But how? not absolutely and simply agreeable unto naturall and religious equitie, in regard of the thing it selfe required, but onely secundum quid, and ex hypothesi, in regard that it was required by him whose authoritie is absolute, and his revealed will the rule of righteousnesse. For set aside the Commandement, and what necessitie or fitnesse can any man by the light
of nature finde in a pigeon or a lambe, more then in an Eagle or a Lyon, to be offered in sacrifice to God? yea what reason why such consecrated things should rather dye then be preserved alive? As types of the all-sufficient perfect sacrifice of Christ, wee may conceive it fit to be so: but then wee goe beyond the bounds of morall duties, and enter into a consideration of an higher nature then humane reason can pretend unto. But in the observation of one day of seven, to be unto the people of God the ordinary time of holy rest, I thinke and I have endeavoured to shew, that nature will acknowledge such a fitnes as is not to be found in any other proportion of time whatsoever. And this I conceive is a maine difference, that may be and must be observed and acknowledged to be between such things, as when they are discovered
to be agreeable unto the will of God, may withall by the light of humane reasō be acknowledged to be agreeable unto naturall and religious equitie. As for example; dare any man deny it agreeable unto naturall and religious equitie, that God commanding it, Abraham should sacrifice his sonne, and the Israelites rob the Egyptians? yet neither of them both was Naturalis & perpetui juris. And on the other side, not to covet that which is another mans, is I suppose without question, Naturalis & perpetui juris, and since God hath discovered his will to that purpose, men by that remaining remnant of the light of nature, which they have, may discerne and acknowledge it to be agreeable unto naturall & religious equitie, but that which it may be no man ever would have light upon, if God had not led them to it
by his Law. Saint Paul saith expresly, I had not knowne lust (namely to be sinne) except the Law had said, Thou shalt not covet, Rom. 7.7. The marriage of one man unto one woman onely, appeares to be Naturalis & perpetui juris, by that of the Prophet Malachie, Mal. 2.14. &c. And he proves it by that act of Gods providence in the creation, that he made but one, although he had the residue of the Spirit. Yet who could ever have attained to the knowledge thereof, if God himselfe had not revealed it? So the observation of one day in seven, as a weekly Sabbath, appears to be Naturalis & perpetui juris, by the fourth Commandement, and is proved so to be by that act of Gods providence in the creation, that he disposed all time in respect of use, to be employed in labour, or in rest; and for proportion ordinarily allowed six dayes of labour
unto one of rest: though men peradventure since the fall had never knowne this, if Moses had not recorded the history of the creation. So that, it seemes, of things which appeare upon occasion of divine discovery, and not otherwise to be agreeable unto naturall and religious equitie, one may be Naturalis et perpetui juris, and another not.

Againe, peradventure, some would say (which yet I doe not) that externall and bloudy sacrifices were so farre agreeable unto naturall and religious equitie, that they might still be practised by the people of God, so that it were not with opinion of necessitie, and as types in reference unto Christ to come. What else is the meaning of those words in the Bishop of Ely, pag. 62. Our Saviour although he disannulled the old Law in respect of observation in the time of the Gospel,
yet he established and confirmed the lawfull use thereof in the Christian Church. Which words, if wee should stretch them to their utmost extent, would I doubt not bring both bloudy sacrifices and almost, if not absolutely, all the rites and ceremonies of the Law within the reach of Christian liberty, and then I presume the Sabbath should be no more excluded then the rest. How ever, I perswade my selfe, the generall practise of the Churches of Christ in all places and at all times (which if any thing be, is able to prove a Catholick tradition) in setting apart one day in every week, as their ordinary time of holy rest (which is all that I pretend to be simply and perpetually morall; yea, all that is intended in the fourth Commandement) and in rejecting the use of bloudy sacrifices, and the like, is a sufficient evidence that they
have alwayes entertained a different opinion of the one and of the other. So that it is no necessary consequence to say, that because bloudy sacrifices are not Naturalis & perpetui juris, therfore a seventh day Sabbath is not, though both be agreeable unto naturall and religious equitie, and that seen onely by occasion of divine discovery: since in the one it may be seen, as properly belonging to the thing it selfe, in the other, no otherwise but onely with reference to Gods revealed will.

div.head: The sixt Exception.
div.p:
The reason of the Jewes observation, it seemes, is to be found apparently in the very body of the Commandement, in these words: For in six dayes the Lord made heaven and earth. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
quoniam, nam, enim: and afterward
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
idcirco.
Therefore the Lord blessed the seventh day - the seventh day? Which seventh day? why that wherein he rested: and that was the Jewish Sabbath. This Master Broad stands most upon.

div.head: The Answer.
div.p:
The reason of the Jewes observation, in part, I confesse, is to be found in the Commandement, viz. in that they observed one day in every week, but not in that they observed that day in order, which they did. Neither doe I take that reason which is to be found to be in the body of the Commandement, but added to the explication of it: the body of the Commandement being comprised in those words, Remember the Sabbath day to keepe it holy, whereof the words following are an explication, Sixe dayes, &c.
And that which followeth, For in six dayes, &c. I take to be a reason of the explication, not of the Commandement it self. It is true, Master Broad stands most upon this, that the Commandement designes that day which was observed by the Jewes: and so doth the Bishop of Ely, affirming it to be the literall and specificall object of the Commandement. But this which they stand most upon, for ought I can perceive, hath most need to be, but is least of all proved to bee intended in the Commandement.

The force of the rationall and illative particles, for and therefore, I acknowledge and confesse, they prove strongly that which they are intended to prove, both the sufficiency and the convenience of a seventh day in proportion, one day in every weeke, to be unto the people of God the ordinary time
of holy rest. For in that God observed that proportion himselfe, it may very well be taken to be an evidence of his puppose and intent, that men should observe it too, and use the same division and distinction of time which he himselfe had done, and ordinarily imploy it so. But to inferre a necessitie of observing the same day in order, which was at first observed by God, because the same proportion of time is to be observed by men that was observed by him, is to dispute à dicto secundum quid, ad dictum simpliciter, or petere principium, to take that for granted which may be denyed. That God intended to require of his people the observation of the same proportion of time, cannot in reason be denyed: but that he intended to require of them the observatition of the same order of the time proportioned, cannot I thinke be proved.

div.head: The seventh Exception.
div.p:
I would this resolution were made apparent more fully and clearely. And if it may be so resolved, why doe you make it obligatory onely to Gods people, and not to all men universally? And doe you thinke that the Israelites did one whole day or other every weeke vacate solenni cultui divino, in the time of the grievous Egyptian bondage? or if not, that they did therein violate or goe against a dictate and principle of the Law of nature?
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Wee may put the same case in Christians now adayes under Turkish tyranny and slavery, or the like.

div.head: The Answer.
div.p:
The clearing to the full of this resolution is the thing I labour for: and if it be not as apparent unto
others as it seems to me, I wonder not who know that every man abounds in his owne sence. But since the way of truth is that which I seek, I shall entertain it as a speciall favour from any man that will inform me where I wander from it.

In what sence I make the Commandment obligatory onely to the people of God, and not to all men universally, I did intimate before: not in regard of the subject matter of it, but in regard of a further tye put upon them by the speciall promulgation of it at Mount Sinai: a respect which I take to be equally common to the fourth with the rest of the Commandments.

Your instances of the Israelites in the time of the Egyptian bondage, and Christians now adayes under Turkish tyranny and slaverie, or the like, I acknowledge
to be both of the same nature: and doubt not but that they then might, and these now may, notwithstanding their subjection to such grievous slaverie, sanctifie a Sabbath day vacando cultui divino solenni, and that for one whole day or other in every week, although not with that publick solemnitie which in statu libero, and Rep. pacata, they might have done: yet with such private devotion as God would have been contented to accept from them in that estate, and wherewith they might encourage themselves, and cheer up their own souls as David did, if not in the same, yet in a case not much unlike: Psal. 42. and Psal. 43. throughout. But whether they did so or no, since God in his Word hath not thought good to tell us, I think there is no necessitie at all that we should enquire. And both of them and Christians now adaies
in the case that you propound, I think it more charitie to hope the best, then wisedome to suspect the worst. Which yet if we should suppose and grant, that thereupon it would follow which you seem to fear, that in so doing they did violate or go against a dictate and principle of the Law of Nature; I think it would prove no more then might be pretended, that they did not onely then, but both before and after in the practise of Polygamie: unlesse we will say that to commit adultery was not so much to violate and go against a dictate or principle of the law of nature, as to prophane the Sabbath day in case the fourth Commandment were simply and perpetually morall: which no man can say, but that withall he must confesse that the fourth Commandment is simply and perpetually morall as well as the seventh:
which if it be granted of that one, I hope will not be denyed of the rest.

Besides that, suppose the fourth Commandment had been but a positive law that bound the Israelites, and none but them, to observe one day in every week as the ordinarie time of holy rest, yet the observation thereof might have been as impossible, at least as difficult and dangerous for them afterwards in the time of the Babylonian captivitie (when the enemie mocked at their Sabbaths. Lam. 1.7. when Darius made a Decree that whosoever should ask a Petition of any God, or man, for thirtie dayes, save of the King himself, should be cast into the den of Lyons. Dan. 6.7. And when we may easily beleeve that others as well as Jehojachin and Zedechias were bound in chains, and kept in prison a long time together) as
it would have been before in the time of the Egyptian bondage, or can be for Christians now adayes under Turkish tyrannie.

And shall we think that the Jews did one whole day or other every week vacare solenni cultui divino, in the time of the Babylonian captivitie? Or if not, that they did violate and go against a dictate or principle of the law of nature, in disobeying a positive law of Divine institution, whereof there is no reason at all to conceive they could be ignorant? If the former, why may we not as well conceive that the Israelites did so in the time of the Egyptian bondage? For ought I know, there is as much testimonie in Scripture of the one, as of the other that is of neither any at all. If the latter, this objection will make no more against the simple and perpetuall moralitie of the fourth Cammandment,
then against the morall equitie thereof, if it be taken to be positive: for the divine institution therof, I suppose, wil never be denied, nor that to live in disobedience to a positive law of divine institution which men are sufficiently informed of that it is such, is to violate and go against a dictate and principle of the Law of Nature.

The onely pretence that I can probably conjecture may be made to the contrary is this, that the fourth Commandment was not intended by God to put a bond of obedience upon the Israelites generally as they were men, or as they were entred into speciall covenant with God; but as they were to live in in statu libero, and Rep. pacata: wherein they might have convenient opportunitie and libertie for the solemne exercise of publick worship. And therefore that though the Jews in the
time of the Babylonian captivitie, and other such ex • remities should not have practised obedience unto the fourth Commandment, vacando solenni cultui divino, one whole day or other every week, yet they should not have lived in disobedience unto a positive Law of divine institution, whereof they were not ignorant, and so not have violated or gone against a dictate and principle of the Law of Nature, because in that case the Commandment bound them not; and where there is no Law, there is no transgression.

But to this I answer. First, that there may be solemne actions of religious service privately performed, and that all solemne worship is not publick. For to the solemnitie of any action sundrie circumstances may concurre, whereof to be publickly performed, is but one, and in defect thereof, either any,
or at least some of the rest may serve to make the performance of an action solemne: for I take set and solemne actions to be properly opposed unto sudden and occasionall. I thinke the Church of Rome would hardly be perswaded to confesse that a private Masse were not a part of solemne service, and if she could as easily prove it to be truly religious worship, as she might that the exercise of it is a solemne action, I see not why she should be blamed for it. Nor can I conceive how solemnitie and privacie should not be taken to concurre in that great mourning, whereof the Prophet Zacharie speaks, Zech. 12.11. &c. when all the families that remain shall mourne, every family apart, and their wives apart. What action of religious service amongst the Israelites was more solemne then the celebration of the Passeover?
over? Yet one of the ordinances of it was, that it must be eaten in their private houses by every family apart; and that none must go out of the doore of his house untill the morning. Exod 12.21.22.

Secondly, if it may be truly pretended, that the fourth Commandment as a positive law obliged not the Jews, but onely in statu libero, and Rep. pacata, why may not the like be pretended likewise of other positive Laws as those which • estrained their marriage with other Nations, and eating of unclean beasts, and the like? Which yet it appears they were obliged to even in the time of the Babylonian captivitie, and their greatest extremities. Nay if with the Papists we should thinke that the second Commandment were no more simply and perpetually morall, then the fourth Commandment is pretended to be, but that in respect
of the literall and specificall object of it, it was onely positive, and obliged none other but the people of Israel, why might we not likewise pretend that it bound not them neither, but in statu libero, and Rep. pacata? And so that Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego were more precise then needed, when they chose rather to expect a miracle of deliverance in the fierie fornace, then they would fall down and worship the golden Image which Nebuchadnezzar had set up. And the like may be said of other Commandments.

Thirdly, if we should acknowledge it true, that the fourth Commandment did not oblige the Jews but onely in statu libero, and Rep. pacata, why should this limitation be restrained to it onely upon a pretence that it was but a positive Law, and not as well be extended unto it in case it be simply and
perpetually morall? May not the fourth Commandment still stand in as full force unto Christians, as ever it did unto the Israelites, and yet bind them no more then it did these; save onely then when they might have convenient opportunitie, and libertie of exercising publick worship? If onely publick worship were required of the Israelites on the ordinarie Sabbath, those cases of necessitie wherein they were dispensed with, or rather wherein the Commandment did not oblige them at all, will alter nothing of the nature of it; but that notwithstanding it may be either simply and perpetually, or onely positively morall: for the question now is not whereunto, but when, and whom it binds.

And so, me thinks, this exception is much like that of the Bishop of Ely, page 175. &c. drawn from the necessitie of a morall
possibilitie in all just Laws, which he denyes the Law of the fourth Commandment to be capable of in respect of all Nations. For he granteth that the fourth Commandment made one day of seven a weekly Sabbath, and that the weekly Sabbath was to be a naturall day of twenty foure houres: but he pretends it obligatorie onely to the Jews, not unto all Nations; because, saith he, some Nations have no ordinarie weeks containing seven particular dayes, distinguished each from other by the rising and setting, and by the presence and departure of the Sunne: as those that live in the Northerne Climates under 70.75.80.85. and 90. degrees.

Where first I conceive, there is a mistake of naturall dayes, being divided and distinguished from one another by the rising and setting of the Sunne: which is not
the distinction of naturall dayes (as he understands them, viz. dayes consisting of twentie-foure equall houres a piece) but of artificiall: the naturall day so understood, being properly distinguished by the accesse and recesse of the Sunnes center unto and from the meridionall line, as the artificiall day in that sence is distinguished by the center of the Sunnes accesse unto and recesse from the Horozontall line: all which are discernable even in those climates which he speaketh of, and so the distinction of dayes and weeks, as possible to the people living there as in other places. The occasion of which mistake, may have been the different application of the termes of that distinction by divers men, some calling that the artificiall day, which others call the naturall and vice versa: which not being well observed or not
much regarded, it was easie to slip a genere in genus, and to understand that of the one which was spoken of the other by the same name. And yet to confesse the truth, before we admit that definition of a naturall day, and that distinction of one naturall day from another, we had need to distinguish of a naturall day, that it is either that which is exactly such indeed, or that which is vulgarly accounted such. That which is exactly such indeed, may be called dies mundanus, or periodus aequatoris, being the measure of that motion whereby in the space of twenty-foure equall houres, any one poynt in the aequator, or in any other of the paralell circles is carried round, and brought againe to the selfe same meridionall line: and this of all other divisions of time made by the motions of the heavens, is the most simple, and
alwayes equall to it selfe. That which is vulgarly accounted such, may be called dies solaris, or periodus solis diurna, being the measure of that time, wherein by the diurnall motion of the Universe, the center of the Sunne is carried round, and brought againe unto the same meridionall line: and this of all other divisions of time, made by the motions of the heavens, comes neerest in exact perfection unto that which is made by the diurnall motion of the Universe, but in it selfe is not exactly equall: and of a naturall day in this latter acceptation, must the former passages be understood.

Secondly, if that pretended impossibilitie were granted, he must likewise pretend it impossible that the Jewes should have lived in one of those climates, or else confesse the Law unjust, if the Jewes living there should have been bound to
the obedience of it: unlesse he will pretend that the fourth Commandement did binde the Jewes in some places of the world, but not in all: and then it would follow, that the Jewes by removing of their habitations, might have freed themselves from that yoke of bondage, as some esteeme it to have been.

So in the cases you propose of the Egyptian bondage, and of Turkish tyranny, there is no inconvenience can be pretended to the Israelites then, or Christians now, from the bond of the fourth Commandement, as of a naturall Law, but so, that the Jewes at other times might have been subject to the like, by reason of their obligation to the same, as to a positive Law of divine institution, if it had been intended onely unto them.
